titleInfo.title: Multidimensional Study on Articulation Deficits in Parkinson's Disease

name.namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders
School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation encompasses a series of studies aimed at characterizing the articulatory speech characteristics of individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) and healthy control (HC) speakers using perceptual, acoustic, and kinematic measures. The first study investigated group differences in perceptual, acoustic, and kinematic measures, while the second study explored changes in these measures during conversational, less clear, and more clear speaking conditions. The third study examined the predictive power of acoustic and kinematic measures for perceptual outcomes of intelligibility and articulatory precision. Forty speakers, including 22 with PD and 18 HC speakers, participated in the study. Acoustic and kinematic speech data were collected simultaneously using the Wave System, an electromagnetic articulography device. Participants read the phrases "Buy Bobby a puppy," "Tess told Dan to stay fit," and "Carl got a croaking frog," using three speaking conditions, including conversational, less clear, and more clear speech. Acoustic and kinematic measures were derived from corner vowel tokens and the /aÉª/ diphthong. Perceptual ratings of intelligibility and articulatory precision were obtained from 368 listeners through crowdsourcing. Linear mixed-effects models were employed to analyze group effects (Study 1), speaking condition effects (Study 2), and the predictive relationship between acoustic and kinematic measures and perceptual outcomes (Study 3). Study 1 revealed that speakers with PD exhibited lower intelligibility and articulatory precision ratings, as well as compressed acoustic vowel space areas (VSAs) compared to HC speakers. Study 2 demonstrated that perceptual measures aligned with expectations (i.e., less clear < conversational < more clear), while some acoustic and kinematic measures followed the predicted trend (i.e., acoustic and kinematic distance), and others did not (i.e., kinematic VSA, F2 slope). Study 3 identified acoustic VSA and kinematic distance as strong predictors of intelligibility and articulatory precision, with a stronger association with articulatory precision. In summary, these findings provide valuable insights into the effects of speech clarity cues on perceptual, acoustic, and kinematic measures of articulation in speakers with PD. By utilizing a multidimensional framework, a more comprehensive understanding of dysarthria's effects on speech articulation in individuals with PD emerges. Methodological considerations, including speech stimuli, measurement techniques, and speaker dialect, are discussed in relation to the study outcomes.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Speech-Language Pathology.
dysarthria, motor speech disorders, Parkinson's disease, speech acoustics, speech kinematics
Yunjung Kim, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Kaschak, University Representative; Kaitlin Lansford, Committee Member; Richard Morris, Committee Member.
